questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with headaches and transient blurred vision. Fundoscopy reveals optic disc swelling with indistinct margins and engorged veins. What is the most accurate explanation for the pathogenesis of this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Compression of the central retinal vein.

options.label: B
options.text: Increased CSF pressure causes axoplasmic stasis.

options.label: C
options.text: Inflammation of the optic nerve head.

questions.correct_answer: B. Increased CSF pressure causes axoplasmic stasis.

questions.text: Latent nystagmus is seen in which of the below mentioned condition?

A 50-year-old woman presents with impaired adduction of the left eye on rightward gaze, and the abducting eye shows ataxic nystagmus. There is no noticeable ptosis, and the convergence remains intact. MRI shows a lesion in the brainstem affecting the medial longitudinal fasciculus. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 60-year-old woman presents with difficulty moving her eyes to the right. On examination, she is unable to gaze to the right, but has normal eye movements when gazing to the left, up, and down. There is no weakness in the limbs or facial muscles. Which of the following is the most likely location of the lesion?

A 32-year-old woman presents with blurred vision in her right eye, photophobia and notices that her right pupil appears larger than the left. On examination, her right pupil is mid-dilated and reacts very sluggishly to light and has a sluggish and tonic reaction to accommodation. The left pupil appears normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 30-year-old male has difficulty distinguishing between red and green colours. His occupation requires accurate colour perception. Which of the following is the most appropriate test to quantify and classify the severity of his red-green colour vision deficiency?
questions.explanation:

  • ↳ Farnsworth-Munsell 100-Hue Test (Option B) Measures ability to differentiate between subtle colour differences using hue arrangements. A higher error score indicates poorer colour vision. Detects fine colour discrimination errors. Often used to assess toxic optic neuropathy .
  • ↳ Farnsworth-Munsell 100-Hue Test (Option B)

Based on the ability to correctly identify numbers or patterns formed by dots of different colours. Primarily detects red-green colour blindness. Hardy-Rand-Ritter (H-R-R) plates can detect blue-yellow deficiencies .

Based on the ability to correctly match the samples with the reference colours provided. Originally designed to screen red-green colour blindness. Although not a suitable screening test.

Test

Procedure

Evaluation

Applications

Lantern Tests

(Option D)

Individuals identify various coloured lights emitted from a lantern.

The accuracy of colour identification is evaluated.

Used in occupations requiring accurate colour vision (e.g., aviation, maritime).

 

Example: Edridge-Green lantern.

Farnsworth-Munsell 100-Hue Test

(Option B)

Measures ability to differentiate between subtle colour differences using hue arrangements.

A higher error score indicates poorer colour vision.

Detects fine colour discrimination errors. Often used to assess toxic optic neuropathy.

Ishihara Color Plates

(Option A)

Coloured dots form numbers or patterns designed to challenge individuals with specific deficiencies.

Based on the ability to correctly identify numbers or patterns formed by dots of different colours.

Primarily detects red-green colour blindness. Hardy-Rand-Ritter (H-R-R) plates can detect blue-yellow deficiencies.

Anomaloscope (Nagel, Pickford-Nicolson)

Split visual field: adjust red and green lights to match a yellow field.

Determines severity and type of red-green colour vision deficiency through light adjustments.

Nagel Anomaloscope for red-green anomalies. Pickford-Nicolson for blue-yellow anomalies.

Holmgren’s Wools Test

Subject is asked to make a series of colour-matches from a selection of skeins of coloured wools.

Based on the ability to correctly match the samples with the reference colours provided.

Originally designed to screen red-green colour blindness. Although not a suitable screening test.

questions.text: On examination, a 45-year-old male was found to have repetitive, involuntary horizontal eye movements after looking at a moving striped pattern. He reports no dizziness, and his neurological examination is otherwise unremarkable. The phenomenon he is experiencing is most likely due to which of the following?

A 45-year-old male presents with difficulty moving his eyes upward and convergence-retraction nystagmus triggered by an upward gaze. His pupils react poorly to light but constrict normally when focusing on near objects. Which of the following syndromes is most likely?

A 50-year-old female patient with anisocoria had cocaine drops applied to both eyes. After 60 minutes, the anisocoria increased. To determine whether the lesion is preganglionic or postganglionic, what is the next step in the diagnostic process?

A 48-year-old male with a history of untreated syphilis from several years ago now presents with memory loss, irritability, difficulty walking, and blurred vision. What type of pupil abnormality could be observed in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Reaction

Description

Causes

Amaurotic light reflex

(Option B)

Absence of direct light reflex on the affected side and an absence of consensual light reflex on the normal side.

Optic and retinal lesions on the affected side

Efferent pathway defect

Absence of both direct and consensual light reflex on the affected side and presence of both direct and consensual light reflex on the normal side. Near reflex is also absent on the affected side.
  • Parasympatholytic drugs (e.g. atropine, homatropine)
  • Internal ophthalmoplegia
  • Third-nerve paralysis.

Marcus Gunn pupil or RAPD

(Option A)
  • The pupils paradoxically dilate when the flashlight is swung from the unaffected to the affected eye due to the decreased light perception.
  • It is the first sign of optic nerve disorder.
  • Tested by a swinging flashlight test.

Incomplete optic nerve lesions (Optic neuritis) and severe retinal diseases (Retinopathy, CRVO)

Adie’s Pupil

(Option C)
  • Reaction to light is absent, and the near reflex is very slow and tonic.
  • It is usually unilateral, associated with absent knee jerk and occurs more often in young women.
  • It shows pupillary constriction to 0.125% Pilocarpine due to denervation supersensitivity.

Postganglionic parasympathetic pupillomotor damage.

Argyll Robertson Pupil (ARP)

(Option D)

Reaction to near reflex is present, but light reflex (both direct and consensual) is absent, i.e. there is light near dissociation.

Neurosyphilis

Wernicke's hemianopic pupil

Light reflex is absent when light is thrown on the temporal half of the retina of the affected side and the nasal half of the opposite side, while it is present when the light is thrown on the nasal half of the affected side and the temporal half of the opposite side.

Optic tract lesion

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient exhibits the following pupillary responses: Light is shown in the left eye; the right pupil constricts, but the left pupil remains dilated. Light is shown in the right eye; only the right pupil constricts, while the left pupil remains dilated. Which of the following lesions is most likely responsible for this pattern of pupillary response?
questions.explanation:
Optic Nerve

(Option A)
  • Direct and consensual reactions are lost on the affected side
  • Both are retained on the opposite side (Option D ruled out)
  • Near reflex and lid reflex remain intact.

Medial Chiasma

Bitemporal hemianopia

Lateral Chiasma

Binasal hemianopia.

Optic Tract

Contralateral hemianopia; Wernicke reaction.

Proximal Optic Tract

Normal pupillary reactions

Central Decussation
  • Bilateral reflex paralysis with no reaction to light but retention of near reflex, lid reflexes, and psycho-sensory reactions
  • Argyll Robertson pupil.

Nuclear / Supranuclear Lesion (Option B)

Ipsilateral absolute pupillary paralysis.

Third Nerve Lesion

Absolute pupillary paralysis.

Ciliary Ganglion Lesion

The light reflex is abolished, but the retention of the near reflex is sometimes followed by tonic contraction (Adie pupil).

questions.text: A 62-year-old patient with papilledema has been examined. On fundoscopic examination of the eye obscuration of major blood vessels is found on the disc & vessels leaving the disc, with a significant halo around the disc. According to the Frisen grading system, what is the grade of papilledema?
questions.explanation:
Grading of Papilledema (Modified Frisen Scale)

Grade 1: C-shaped halo nasally.

Grade 2: Circumferential halo around the optic disc.

Grade 3: Obscuration of one or more major vessels leaving the disc.

Grade 4: Obscuration of major vessels on the disc.

Grade 5: Complete obscuration of all vessels on and leaving the disc

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient presents with worsening headaches and visual disturbances. Fundoscopic examination reveals optic disc swelling. Which of the following is least likely to be associated with this condition?

options.label: C
options.text: Blurring of the optic disc margins

questions.explanation:
Stages

Description

Early Papilledema
  • Blurring of optic disc margins, disc hyperemia, and mild disc swelling.
  • Normal visual field & acuity.

Fully Developed Papilledema
  • Significant optic disc elevation, engorged veins, and peripapillary haemorrhages.
  • Transient disturbance of vision.

Chronic Papilledema
  • Disc cup obliteration, reduced hyperemia, and hard exudates
  • Visual acuity decreases, & Constriction of the visual field.

Late Papilledema

Optic atrophy, reduced disc swelling, and a grey, blurred disc appearance.

questions.text: A 62-year-old patient presents with difficulty seeing objects in the right half of the visual field in both eyes. Based on this clinical presentation, which of the following is the most likely location of the lesion affecting the visual pathway?
questions.explanation:
Components of Visual Pathway

Retina
  • First-order Neurons: Bipolar cells in the inner nuclear layer of the retina.
  • Second-order Neurons: Ganglion cells in the retina; their axons form the optic nerve.

Optic Nerve
  • Carries visual information from the retina to the optic chiasm.
  • Temporal and Nasal fibres of the same eye.

Optic Chiasma
  • Partial decussation occurs
  • Nasal fibres cross to the opposite side, while temporal fibres remain ipsilateral.

Optic Tract
  • Carries visual information from the optic chiasms to the Lateral Gebiculate body(LGB).
  • Temporal fibres of the same eye and Nasal fibres of the opposite eye.
  • The lesion causes Homonymous Hemianopia in the opposite eye.

Lateral Geniculate Body (LGB)
  • Third Order Neurons: Relay visual information to the visual cortex.

Optic Radiations
  • Meyer's Loop: Carries information from lower retinal quadrants to the inferior part of the visual cortex.
  • Baum’s Loop (Dorsal): Carries information from upper retinal quadrants to the superior part of the visual cortex.

Occipital Cortex

The primary visual cortex (V1), corresponding to Brodmann area 17, is situated on the medial side of the occipital lobe, particularly along the borders of the calcarine fissure.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient with multiple sclerosis (MS) notices that her vision becomes temporarily blurred whenever she exercises. Which of the following phenomena is most likely explained by this temporary worsening of neurological symptoms due to increased body temperature?

A 45-year-old man presents with progressive bilateral vision loss over the past few months. He reports a history of heavy smoking and alcohol consumption. Examination reveals a centrocecal scotoma in both eyes, and fundoscopy shows mild temporal pallor of the optic discs, as shown in the image. Which of the following substances is most likely responsible for his condition?
questions.explanation:
Category

Agents

Mechanism of Action

Exogenous Poisons

Tobacco (Cyanide), Ethyl Alcohol (Ethanol), Methyl Alcohol (Methanol), Ethylene Glycol (Antifreeze), Lead, Arsenic, Cannabis indica (Tetrahydrocannabinol), Carbon Disulfide (Industrial Solvent)

These toxins directly affect optic nerve function through mitochondrial dysfunction or systemic toxicity.

Medications

Digoxin, Disulfiram, Isoniazid, Chloroquine, Cyanide, Ethambutol, Quinine, Streptomycin, Amiodarone, Sulfasalazine, Vigabatrin

These drugs interfere with cellular metabolism or have neurotoxic effects on the optic nerve, leading to vision loss.

Nutritional Deficiency

B Vitamins (especially B12, Thiamine, Folate)

Deficiencies in these vitamins lead to nerve damage, including the optic nerve.

Metabolic Disorders

Diabetic ketoacidosis, Uremia

These conditions cause metabolic disturbances that can damage the optic nerve.

questions.text: A 72-year-old patient presents with sudden vision loss in one eye, severe headache, scalp tenderness, and jaw claudication. Fundoscopic examination reveals a pale, swollen optic disc with haemorrhages. Laboratory tests show elevated ESR and CRP levels. What is the diagnosis and the appropriate management?
questions.correct_answer: C. Arteritic AION; High dose corticosteroids
questions.explanation:
Feature

Arteritic AION (AAION)

Non-Arteritic AION (NAION)

Cause

Inflammation and potential blood clot formation due to Giant Cell Arteritis (GCA)

No inflammatory process; unclear reason for blood vessel blockage

Prevalence

5-10% of AION cases

90-95% of AION cases

Typical Age

Around 70 years

Middle-aged to older adults (usually over 50)

Risk Factors
  • Age > 50
  • Northern European descent
  • Other autoimmune diseases
  • Diabetes
  • Hypertension
  • Atherosclerosis
  • Crowded optic disc

Symptoms

Severe headache

Scalp tenderness

Jaw claudication

Systemic symptoms like fever and fatigue

Sudden vision loss (painless)

Altitudinal field defect

Relative Afferent Pupillary Defect (RAPD)

Ophthalmoscopic Findings
  • Pale and swollen optic disc
  • Cotton wool spots
  • Splinter haemorrhages

Swollen and hyperemic optic disc

Visual Field Defect

Inferior altitudinal defects are common

Diagnostic Tests
  • Elevated ESR and CRP
  • Temporal artery biopsy
  • Fluorescein angiography
  • Visual field testing

Management
  • High-dose corticosteroids
  • Long-term low-dose corticosteroids
  • No proven treatment
  • Manage risk factors through lifestyle modifications
  • Low-dose aspirin (can be used sometimes)

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman presents with a history of decreased vision in her right eye. On examining the right eye, there is RAPD, pain on eye elevation, and the fundus is normal. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.explanation:
Management of Optic neuritis

Treatment

Indications

Details

Conservative management

(Observation and Monitoring)
  • Mild symptoms
  • Known history of similar episodes
  • Many cases improve spontaneously.
  • Suitable for mild symptoms but not recommended for severe cases or first episodes.

High-Dose Corticosteroids
  • Severe vision loss
  • No history of previous episodes
  • MRI evidence of demyelination
  • Intravenous methylprednisolone (1 g daily for 3 days) followed by oral prednisolone taper as established by the ONTT trial (Optic Neuritis Treatment Trial).
  • It accelerates visual recovery but does not prevent future multiple sclerosis episodes. Patients with optic neuritis when related to MS can also be given Glatiramer acetate and Beta Interferon 1a.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with a 3-week history of difficulty in vision in her left eye, along with persistent headaches and occasional eye pain. She also reports trouble with colour perception. Fundoscopic examination reveals the findings shown in the image. Which type of optic neuritis is most likely to be seen?
questions.explanation:
Papillitis

(Option A)

Retrobulbar Neuritis

(Option B)

Neuroretinitis

(Option C)

Site

Optic disc

Optic nerve behind the eyeball.

Optic disc and surrounding retina in the macular area.

Characteristic features

Fundoscopy reveals a blurred disc margin due to leakage and increased capillary permeability, edematous and hyperaemic disc, and physiological cup is obliterated.
  • Pain on eye elevation
  • RAPD (relative afferent pupillary defect) is observed.
  • Fundoscopic examination typically reveals normal optic disc, at least initially, which is why the classic phrase, “the patient sees nothing, and the doctor sees nothing” is often used to describe retrobulbar neuritis.

A macular star is seen in fundoscopy (accumulation of lipids).

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman has a 6-month history of worsening vision and difficulty with detailed tasks, along with occasional eye pain in her left eye. Fundoscopy shows a chalky white optic disc with normal vessels in her left eye. What is the most common cause of these findings?
questions.explanation:
Primary

Secondary

Consecutive

Glaucomatous

Pathology
  • Refers to the degeneration of the nerve fibres
  • Seen in the retrolaminar area.

Occurs following any pathologic condition or disease.

Occurs following destruction of ganglion cells secondary to lesions of the choroid and/ or retina

Occurs due to long-standing glaucoma.

Etiology
  • Multiple sclerosis (Option B)
  • Retrobulbar neuritis
  • Leber's hereditary optic atrophies
  • Intracranial tumours (e.g. pituitary tumours)
  • Traumatic severance or avulsion of the optic nerve
  • Toxic amblyopia (chronic retrobulbar neuritis)
  • Tabes dorsalis.
  • Long-standing optic nerve disease.
  • Papilledema (Option A)
  • Diffuse chorioretinitis
  • Retinal pigmentary dystrophies (e.g., retinitis pigmentosa (Option C), pathological myopia and occlusion of the central retinal artery)

Glaucoma

(Option D)

Fundoscopy

  • Chalky white
  • Clear disc margin
  • Lamina cribrosa well seen
  • Normal vessels.

 
  • Dirty grey
  • Clear disc margin
  • Lamina cribrosa obscured
  • Peripapillary sheathing over vessels
  • Hyaline bodies on the retina.
  • Waxy pallor
  • Blurred disc margin
  • Lamina cribrosa well seen
  • Attenuated vessels

 

Characterized by deep and wide cupping of the optic disc and nasal shift of the blood vessels.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female reports a gradual decline in vision in her right eye over the past three months, accompanied by blurry vision and impaired colour perception in that eye. Upon examination, the ophthalmologist suspected optic nerve damage and advised further tests. Which of the following manifestations does not indicate optic nerve dysfunction?
questions.explanation:
Central scotoma (most common) (Option C)

Centrocecal scotoma

Altitudinal field defect

questions.text: Which of the following arteries contributes to the formation of the Circle of Zinn-Haller?

A 62-year-old patient presents with a visual field defect following a stroke. Neuroimaging reveals a lesion in the occipital lobe related to the territory of the posterior cerebral artery affecting the calcarine cortex. Which of the following visual field characteristics is most likely associated with this type of lesion?

options.label: A
options.text: Congruous Homonymous Hemianopia with Macular Sparing

options.label: B
options.text: Congruous Homonymous Hemianopia without Macular Sparing

options.label: C
options.text: Incongruous homonymous hemianopia with Macular sparing

options.label: D
options.text: Incongruous homonymous hemianopia without Macular sparing

questions.correct_answer: A. Congruous Homonymous Hemianopia with Macular Sparing

questions.text: A 58-year-old patient presents with visual disturbances. Neuroimaging reveals a lesion in the temporal lobe affecting the inferior optic radiations. Which visual field defects are most likely associated with this finding?
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Inferior Optic Radiations

(Meyer’s Loop)

Superior Optic Radiations

(Baum’s Loop)

Location of Lesion

Temporal lobe

Parietal lobe

Affected Visual Field

Superior quadrants of the contralateral visual field of both eyes

Inferior quadrants of the contralateral visual field of both eyes.

Visual Defect

Superior homonymous quadrantanopia

Inferior homonymous quadrantanopia (Option A)

Associated Symptoms
  • Memory loss
  • Hearing loss
  • Auditory hallucinations
  • Contralateral hemiplegia
  • Hemianesthesia
  • Optokinetic nystagmus

questions.text: A 58-year-old patient presents with right-sided visual field loss in both eyes, resulting in a homonymous hemianopic defect. Neuroimaging and clinical examination suggest a lesion affecting the visual pathway. Based on the above findings, which anatomical location is most likely implicated in this patient's condition?
questions.explanation:
Location of the lesion

Characteristic features

Optic nerve
  • Marked loss of vision or complete blindness on the affected side associated.
  • Near (accommodation) reflex is present.

Optic chiasma
  • Bitemporal hemianopia

Optic tract
  • Contralateral homonymous hemianopia
  • Contralateral hemianopic pupillary responses, i.e. Wernicke's reaction.

Optic radiations
  • Superior quadrantic hemianopia (pie in the sky)
    • Produced when the inferior fibres (Meyer’s loop) are involved in temporal lobe lesions)
  • Inferior quadrantic hemianopia (pie on the floor)
    • Produced when superior fibres (Baum’s loop) are involved in parietal lobe lesions.

Visual cortex
  • Homonymous hemianopia, often with macular sparing

questions.text: A 64-year-old patient presents with difficulty seeing objects. MRI findings reveal a pituitary adenoma causing compression at the optic chiasma. Which visual field defect is most likely associated with this condition?
questions.explanation:
Visual Pathway Lesions and Defects

Site of Lesion

Fibers Affected

Field Defect

Optic Nerve

Ipsilateral Temporal + Nasal Fibers

  

Anopia

Optic Chiasma

Bilateral Nasal Fibers

Bitemporal Hemianopia

(Heteronymous Hemianopia)
  • Optic Tract
  • Lateral Geniculate Body (LGB Lesion)
  • Optic Radiation

Ipsilateral Temporal Fibers + Contralateral Nasal Fibers

Homonymous Hemianopia

(Option C)

Visual Cortex without the involvement of tip

(Post. Cerebral Artery)

Ipsilateral Temporal Fibers + Contralateral Nasal Fibers except macular representation

Homonymous Hemianopia with Macular Sparing

(Option D)

Tip of Visual Cortex

(Middle Cerebral Artery)

Macular Representation of Ipsilateral Temporal and Contralateral Nasal Fibers.

Macular Homonymous Hemianopia
